message.content: This question requires basic knowledge of the concept of inherited characteristics and variation in species. The varying number of body parts in different species is attributed to inherited characteristics, meaning it is determined by genetic factors that are passed down from parents to offspring. Option (A) is incorrect because survival is a general concept that applies to all living organisms, not specifically to the number of body parts. Option (B) is incorrect because environmental growth does not determine the number of body parts in a species. Option (D) is incorrect because developmental abilities refer to an organism's capacity to grow and develop, not specifically to the number of body parts.

This question requires knowledge about the variation in body parts among different species and the factors that contribute to this variation. The varying number of body parts in different species, such as arachnids and humans, can be attributed to inherited characteristics. This means that the number of body parts an organism has is determined by its genetic makeup and inherited from its parents. Option (A) is incorrect because while having the right number of body parts may contribute to survival, the question is asking about the cause of the variation in body parts. Option (B) is incorrect because environmental growth does not determine the number of body parts an organism has. Option (D) is incorrect because developmental abilities refer to an organism's ability to grow and develop, but it does not directly relate to the number of body parts an organism has.

This question requires some knowledge about variation in body parts across different species and the concept of inherited characteristics. The varying numbers of body parts in different species, such as arachnids and humans, can be attributed to inherited characteristics. Inherited characteristics are traits that are passed down from one generation to the next through genes. These traits determine the physical characteristics and structures of an organism, including the number of body parts. Option (A) is incorrect because while having body parts may aid in survival, the number of body parts itself is not directly connected to survival. Option (B) is not relevant to the question as it does not explain the varying numbers of body parts. Option (D) is also incorrect because developmental abilities do not determine the number of body parts in different species, but rather the genetic information inherited from previous generations.
